lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters and actions mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “Listen for run, dance, draw.” Play story audio. Students raise hands or draw tally marks each time they hear a target word.
stretchStrategies: Story Switch-Up: After acting out the original story, ask students to change one action and act out the new version. Then describe the change: “In our story, he isn’t walking. He’s running!”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read the story aloud. Students echo each sentence. Assign roles and act out using gestures and simple props.
stretchStrategies: Story Switch-Up: After acting out the original story, ask students to change one action and act out the new version. Then describe the change: “In our story, he isn’t walking. He’s running!”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or acting it out.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Show the last image of the story. Ask: “What could happen next?” Students draw or describe a new scene.

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.

Systematic kinds of silent letters, such as 'magic e' in late or mote, or silent gh in thought and bought, are entirely alien to Vietnamese. They are often acquired as sight words first; the teacher can explain at higher levels.

Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
